content.description: Understand the foundations of technical analysis, including its purpose and how it differs from fundamental analysis.

topics.content: Technical analysis involves evaluating securities by analyzing statistical trends gathered from trading activity, such as price movement and volume. It focuses on charts and patterns to predict future price movements.
Technical analysis helps traders identify opportunities in the market by studying historical price patterns. Itâ€™s especially useful for short-term trading and complements fundamental analysis.

content.description: Learn about the most commonly used technical indicators and how they can guide trading decisions.

topics.content: Moving averages smooth out price data to identify trends over a specific period. Common types include Simple Moving Averages (SMA) and Exponential Moving Averages (EMA).
RSI measures the speed and change of price movements to identify overbought or oversold conditions. Values above 70 indicate overbought conditions, while values below 30 suggest oversold conditions.
Bollinger Bands consist of a middle band (SMA) and two outer bands that represent standard deviations. They help traders identify volatility and potential price breakouts.

content.description: Discover key chart patterns and how they signal potential price movements.

topics.content: The head and shoulders pattern is a reversal formation that predicts a change in trend direction. It consists of three peaks: the middle peak is higher (head), and the other two are lower (shoulders).
Double tops signal a bearish reversal, while double bottoms indicate a bullish reversal. These patterns form when prices test the same support or resistance levels twice before reversing.
Flags and pennants are continuation patterns that appear after strong price movements. They suggest that the trend will resume once the pattern completes.

content.description: Learn how to interpret volume data and its significance in confirming price movements.

topics.content: Volume reflects the number of shares or contracts traded during a period. It confirms the strength of price movements: high volume indicates stronger trends, while low volume suggests weaker trends.
Popular volume indicators include the On-Balance Volume (OBV) and the Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP). These tools provide insights into buying and selling pressure.
